reviewText: Given the many times I have heard the phrase "Good morning Mr. Phelps" it was a little unnerving to see Steven Hill in the role of Mr. Briggs, the leader of the IM force. While this pilot episode of the series has a few rough edges that were quickly ironed out, one of the surprises was when Barbara Bain as Cinnamon walks out the door clad only in a towel. It was so skimpy that it is surprising that it passed the rigorous censorship rules of the time. She was hot!The dictator of a Caribbean island has managed to acquire two tactical nuclear warheads and he has them stored in a very strong safe with a time lock. Their mission is to take the warheads out of the safe and get them out of the country. Wally Cox also stars as a safecracker, it is too bad that he didn't continue the role in the series; it is easy to imagine the many possibilities. Rollin Hand is to impersonate the dictator long enough for the IM team to extract the weapons, so he must study the man firsthand and be ready to take his place. Mr. Briggs portrays a dealer in valuable Swiss watches and Willy is his valet, carrying around very large cases.The tactics used by the IM force in this pilot demonstrated very quickly and effectively how interesting the show would be. There would be no brute force blowing of the safe, the IM team were subtle, deceptive and manipulative, making their opposition believe X when they should be thinking Y.Mr. Phelps is the leader of the IM team in "The Photographer", where an American photographer is the leader of a vast spy network that is trying to smuggle a deadly plague organism into the United States. Teams of cryptographers have failed to crack the code, so it is up to the IM force to acquire the decoding keys. The two spy leaders have their communication equipment in a sophisticated bomb shelter and it will be necessary for the IM force to convince the spies that a nuclear attack has taken place on the United States and that they must send a message to their handlers. Cinnamon takes on the role of a fashion model in order to gain access to the photographer and his base of operations.The tactics used are very imaginative and thoughtful, demonstrating excellent writing and cerebral storylines. Looking back on the show and the times, one is reminded how unusual the character of Barney Collier was. Given the stereotypes so prevalent at the time, the "natural" role for the black man would have been as the muscle. Yet, Barney was the technical expert of the team, the man with the most sophisticated technical skills in the group.
summary: Cerebral, complicated plots that often had you puzzled
Title: The Best of Mission Impossible, Volume 1 VHS

reviewText: I saw many of the Mission Impossible series as a teenager.  I also read the original paperback book when it came out which was made as Vol. #7.  Steven Hill playing Daniell Briggs (the first season-I understand that Steven would have continued with the series but because of his religious convictions he was not able to fulfill the long work schedules) and Peter Graves ( all subsequent seasons) as Jim Phelps both play excellent as the genius mastermind Team leader of the Impossible Mission Force (IMF) a top American government group virtually unknown to the rest of the top secret agencies.  During his college days Dan or Jim majored in psychology at a top west coast university and was a chess champion.  The rest of the IMF is composed of the beautiful model and Fem Fatale, Cinnamon Carter played by Barbara Bain is excellent.  The academy award winner, Martin Landau who eventually married Barbara plays Rollin Hand, the magician and master of disguise. Black actor, Greg Morris does a superb job as Barney Collier, electronics genius with a prestigious background.  The strong man or weight lifting world record holder, William (Willie) Armitage played by Peter Lupus is the brawn on the Team.  he certainly looked the part also.  Together the IMF carries out  missions against impossible odds to rescue people, con enemy states, and change the courses of governments for the betterment of the free world especially without causing wars.  This first volume is excellent in introducing this Team of specialists with exciting and intruiging plots and ways the IMF thwarts and bamboozles the opponent in the pilot and also in the second story called the Photographer which Anthony Zerbe stars.  All of the Mission Impossible series are excellent and demonstrates how things can be accomplished through nonviolent methods also.  The CIA actually did accomplish some similiar things which are now becoming declassified.  This show was one of my favorite TV shows in the sixties and early seventies.  You will enjoy them as well!!
Title: The Best of Mission Impossible, Volume 1 VHS

reviewText: In my opinion, no other spy thriller from the Cold War was better defined than that of Mission:Impossible. A great cast of characters each specialized for the government, Master of Disguise, Rollin Hand aka Martin Landau, Cinammon Carter, aka Barbara Bain and then there's Greg Morris as Barney Collier, Peter Lupas as Willie the Strong Man,Peter Graves as Jim Phelps and Steven Hill as Dan Briggs. M:I is due on DVD this September. Its about time!!!
Title: The Best of Mission Impossible, Volume 1 VHS

reviewText: Great Series , Great Cast, Great Stories along the lines of 007 I remember watching this growing up and wondering if I could ever get the set, I have grown older and I still enjoy the series. Lets Get It Out on DVD ASAP, Thanks
Title: The Best of Mission Impossible, Volume 1 VHS

reviewText: This was and is still a great show with a great cast.  With all the other old TV shows making it to DVD, they need to start releasing season sets of this spectacular show.
summary: A Great Show - Bring it to DVD!
Title: The Best of Mission Impossible, Volume 1 VHS

reviewText: "Mission Impossible" originally ran from 1966 and 1973, telling tales of the Impossible Mission Force, a group of highly specialized government agents who were usually involved in disrupting the activities of small foreign powers trying to mess with the United States and the Free World.  The group leader, Daniel Briggs (Steven Hill) in the first season and Jim Phelps (Peter Graves) for the rest of the show's run, put together the team and developed the complex plan to pull off the impossible mission; Cinnamon Carter (Barbara Bain) was the the beautiful female member of the team, Rollin Hand (Martin Landau) the master of disguise, Barney Collier (Greg Morris) was the electronics expert, and William Armitage (Peter Lupus) the muscle.This first tape in the "Mission Impossible" series has the pilot and a choice episode from the show's second season.  In the pilot episode (9/17/66), Wally Cox plays a safecracker who has to sneak into the vault of a hotel to steal a couple of nuclear warheads from a military dictator.  This was the only episode of the show written by series creator Bruce Geller.  This is not a classic episode per se, but it clearly sets the template for the entire series.  "The Photographer" (12/17/67), written by two of the show's most productive writers, William Read Woodfield and Allan Balter, deals with biological warfare.  Enemy agents intend to spread pneumonic plague and a top photographer (Anthony Zerbe) is the key contact.  The IMF fakes a nuclear attack on New York to get the key to the code.  Yes, there is a large degree of irony in watching this particular episode today, but remember what things were like in the Sixties.  "The Photographer" is a classic MI episode and along with the pilot makes this an excellent tape to have for fans of the series.Final Note: For my money the title sequence for this show is definitely one of the ten best ever, not just because of Lalo Schifrin's memorable theme music but because of the way shots from the episode were mixed in with the burning fuse and shots of the cast.  You always saw enough to get interested in what was to happen, but they never let the cat out of the bag enough to ruin the episode.
summary: Introducing you to the Cold War and the IMF Team
Title: The Best of Mission Impossible, Volume 1 VHS
